text: Actually, all our OpEds are 800-1000 words, if you're reading our page, so if you're pitching a 450 word OpEd to me, you're already screwing up. But also, I literally am not going to stop my workflow to read an email while someone's on the phone, which is what they're asking.
author: megancarpentier

text: Emails *to a reporter* should be short (3-5 sentences), succinct and lay out that you're here to help, with one follow up if there is a story on the beat breaking or that you know is coming. The editors on the beat don't usually hand out experts to reporters.
author: megancarpentier

text: Now, to point out, I'm not new to the beat and, on this beat, I'm not remotely unique in this; how am I supposed to find in my inbox, read, assess, and tell you if the 1,000 word OpEd you've pitched is one I will accept, while you're on the phone? That's the ask that annoys.

text:
A great technique to record interviews in this, the year of our Lord 2019:
1. Download free recording app for your cell phone.
2. Ask permission to record
3. Hit the record button on your app
4. Turn off your phone screen
5. Set phone down/hold it with bent arm
6. Look at person

text: I mean, just some friendly advice. I hear it a lot, and it's clearly one big thing that keeps people from being successful freelancers. People who pitch me, take a no, and pitch me again later are the ones I end up pubbing a bunch (and ditto everyone else).
author: megancarpentier

text: And everyone else is exactly the same. You're ginning yourself up about exactly nothing!
author: megancarpentier

text: Literally, I get dozens of pitches per day, multiplied by 7 days a week going on 5 years. Unless you are a dick about it, write something really racist/homo/transphobic/sexist, there's not enough space in my head to have ideas about it 5 minutes after saying no.
author: megancarpentier

text: Why work up the courage? The worst anyone is going to say is "no." You can't look at it like asking people to marry you or some shit. Pitch and onto the next.
author: megancarpentier

text: I don't mind pushbacks on individual things about which someone feels strongly (though 95% of the time, I identify those things and explain why in a cover note so the person needs to justify). But some people are just anti-editing, period.
author: megancarpentier

text: I think the free-for-all of the former HuffPo blogs gave a lot of people the impression that submission/publication is all there is to the process and that their unedited copy was awesome. Or at least that's what I blame for it.
author: megancarpentier

text: It's really annoyingly time consuming, actually! It's just marginally less time-consuming than editing someone's crappy copy who then refuses all edits and flounces.

text: Me, whenever I hear that, "Good luck in self-publishing!" (This is, quite literally, why I now explain to anyone who cold pitches me that we edit all pieces, and we do not simply publish "submissions.")

text: Our maternal mortality rate is equally shameful: every year 700-900 women die after childbirth and 65,000 nearly do. That’s nearly 4 times the rate elsewhere in the developed world:
author: megancarpentier

text: The biggest cause of our (insanely high!) infant mortality rate is... congenital malformations, deformations and chromosomal abnormalities. That and short gestation/low birth weight disorders (ie, premature delivery) account for 38 percent of US infant mortality.
author: megancarpentier

text: The neonatal mortality rate (death within 28 days of birth) is 4 in every 1,000 live births, or 15,413 babies in 2018, give or take. That’s 83% higher than elsewhere in the developed world.
author: megancarpentier

text: If you’re doing math, that’s about 22,735 infants who died in 2018.
author: megancarpentier

text: So, just FYI, infant end of life decisions are a daily reality in the United States, where the infant mortality rate (5.9 per every 1,000 live births in the first year of life) is 71% higher than any other developed country.

text: Anyway, it's not just about calories, it's about which calories, and it's not just about one day of junk food but about breaking cycles for these kids who, yeah, prolly ate a lot of junk food in high school just to get enough calories.
author: megancarpentier

text: And, football players and college wrestlers are as vulnerable to binge/purge or binge/over-execise cycles as other elite athletes, with serious deleterious health consequences after they stop being athletes, which trainers and nutritionists have recognized over the years.
author: megancarpentier

text: She doesn't have cheat days (and not just because of the weight questions), but because she can't afford to fuck up her joints or forego the lean proteins and veggies her body needs to stay in performance shape.
author: megancarpentier

text: Meanwhile, my other cousin is a professional ballerina and works incredibly closely with her trainers, coaches and nutritionists to constantly tweak and refine her nutrition and training regimen in order to stay in competitive shape and have the calories and nutrients she needs.
author: megancarpentier

text: My cousin was a recruited college athlete and flopped out of two programs in no small part because he just couldn't quit the junk food, nor the rush he got from it. But he also had no stamina and didn't grow as an athlete after his first year in either.
author: megancarpentier

text: So, the thing about feeding elite athletes junk food: Yes, they can process the calories and yes they enjoy it. But their trainers and nutritionists (and you best believe they have both) must've been grinding their teeth the whole time.

text: Which, lol if Paul Ryan is claiming that eminent domaine seizures for economic development purposes isn’t a federal issue nowadays.

text: Donald Trump’s open and ongoing support for it caused not-insignificant consternation among movement conservatives in 2015, likely since quieted by the idea that Congressional and state Republicans could rein him in (Example: https://reason.com/blog/2015/10/06/donald-trump-thinks-kelo-style-eminent-d/amp …)
author: megancarpentier

text: The Kelo decision, for non-property rights nerds, was the Supreme Court decision that allowed government to seize land under eminent domain to hand it over to private developers if there was an “economic development” argument. Reversing it was a cause célèbre among conservatives.

text: Anyway, trying to shame readers about being interested in Kanye and Kim K. into voting is... not a solution to governments reducing citizens' access to franchise and is elitist and condescending and ignorant as fuck about the real challenges of voter participation.
author: megancarpentier

text: Any/all of these can be solved with early voting, absentee voting, voting by mail, automatic voter registration and robust programs connecting people with transportation options -- like that bus in Georgia that voters were forced to get off this week :
author: megancarpentier

text: Note that the others are about access to the polls, which has been significant reduced in the last decade: illness, disability, transportation problems, inability to get out of work, or out of town on the day of the election.
author: megancarpentier

text: A Pew study from 2016 adds more to that list from voters' own mouths; notably frustration with the quality of our choices at the ballot box and a feeling that our votes don't actually matter are the top two. https://www.americanprogress.org/issues/democracy/reports/2018/07/11/453319/increasing-voter-participation-america/ …
author: megancarpentier

text: Also the reasons that people don't vote are long established, and include massive disenfranchisement and other barriers that states erect to voting (like, say, reducing the number of polling places and reducing the hours to vote)!

text: P.S., if history books aren't your thing, I recommend Nasty Girl (about a German girl discovering the complicity of her anti-Nazi town), currently for rent on Amazon Prime. Or The White Rose, if you can find it, is super watchable as well.
author: megancarpentier

text: But the idea that everyday Germans were just like, "oh, we don't want to hurt Nazis' feelings by being mean" is intensely ahistoric. Many, many Germans were collaborators. Silence was legitimate complicity (even Niemöller, who penned that poem you love: https://www.ushmm.org/wlc/en/article.php?ModuleId=10007391 …)
author: megancarpentier

text: FYI, because I hate historical inaccuracy, German politics were not precisely "civil" in the 20s and 30s and if opposition got a lot quieter after 1932-34, it's because Hitler's regime was imprisoning and killing the vocal opposition.

text: Generally speaking, US law is much, much more liberal than Canadian/British/European law on these matters and news orgs have far more leeway.
author: megancarpentier

text: From the Reporters Committed for Freedom of the Press, what is a defense to publication of private facts, if not truth? Newsworthiness. https://www.rcfp.org/first-amendment-handbook/other-newsgathering-concerns-defenses …
author: megancarpentier

text: From the Digital Media Law Project, some facts the courts have found to be private under various circumstances. http://www.dmlp.org/legal-guide/publication-private-facts …
author: megancarpentier

text: If you didn't know, this is a general standard under which news orgs and reporters can be sued by private individuals for invasion of privacy, and the courts determine what is really newsworthy and what is not.
author: megancarpentier

text: So, just randomly, was reading some background on the law on the publication of private facts, which is a legal thing journalists should know because it gives someone the ability to sue you, and truthfulness is not a defense.
author: megancarpentier

text: And also I guess I would add that a news site publishing the private contact information of people opens them up to significant legal jeopardy, which is well established. http://www.dmlp.org/legal-guide/publication-private-facts …
author: megancarpentier

text: He does not personally have subpoena power. But the DOJ/FBI/DC police do, to investigate violations of federal/district law. And maybe it is smart for people who don't want to be investigated for potential harassment not pile on when they know someone is being harassed.

author: megancarpentier

text: The internet in 2018 is probably not going to validate your feelings/hurt/righteousness.
author: megancarpentier

text: *A larger point that comes across* is why you should have a good editor/good friend read it and comment on it honestly. If it doesn't or there isn't one, save it for the memoir/email it to a few friends for the validation you're actually seeking.
author: megancarpentier

text: If you are still smarting and super emotional/angry in any way, sit on it until you can read it without hurting/crying/being mad/wanting the other person to feel a kind of way. Then re-read, edit and make sure there's a larger point that comes across.
author: megancarpentier

text: If you're writing it to get back/hurt someone in particular, well, be really sure that you are willing to take a raft of shit just to hurt someone else's feelings (assuming that it'll hurt someone else's feelings! It might not!).
author: megancarpentier

text: If your editor asks you to recast, edits it a ton and/or says some version of "Are you realllly sure you want to publish this," s/he is telling you that you will potentially not come off well, and you should think about what that really means for your day/your future as a writer.
author: megancarpentier

text: Your editor is your friend but not your therapist! S/he can save you from yourself but might choose not to, and you may be so tiresome in editing that s/he throws up her hands and releases you to the forces of the internet. That is... cruel, but it happens.
author: megancarpentier

text: In fact, one short essay that I posted to my now-deleted Tumblr caused a permanent rift with one particular ex whose fuck-you email I still have, so I think I know a little about causing damage with your personal writing. So, thoughts!

author: megancarpentier

text: Also, this is really first/second semester basic economics, and shout-out to Mr. Palmer, my high school economics teacher, for touching on this stuff back in the day. Economic literacy is more important than you think.
author: megancarpentier

text: So the questions are: how much more are you, the average consumer, willing to pay for everything you buy in order to "bring back" American manufacturing, and how much in exporters' profits are you willing to sacrifice to do that?
author: megancarpentier

text: Now, how high do we have to raise tariffs (and thus the cost of goods to consumers) to "bring back" American manufacturing, assuming that could even really work in 2018? REALLY HIGH.
author: megancarpentier

text: It's also had negative effects on companies in America that, for various reasons, couldn't produce things more cheaply than the cost of making them elsewhere and transporting them here.
author: megancarpentier

text: Broadly over time, reducing tariffs has reduced prices for US consumers on most things we buy, from cars to clothes to electronics to whatever. Everything you wear or carry or sit on or eat or drink or type on that didn't come from America is cheaper than without "free" trade.
author: megancarpentier

text: And the misbehaving country is not allowed to retaliate in kind. One of the biggest users of this system is... the United States. https://www.wto.org/english/thewto_e/20y_e/dispute_brochure20y_e.pdf …
author: megancarpentier

text: So if you unilaterally impose broad tariffs on goods without showing evidence that the other party or parties had actually violated rules (including country of origin sourcing!), they get to impose retaliatory tariffs on you, raising the prices of your goods in their countries.
author: megancarpentier

text: The other big feature of more "free" trade (which is not, again, really that "free") is reciprocity and the ability to resolve conflicts/punish countries that aren't living up to the standards of any given agreement.
author: megancarpentier

text: (Writ large, of course: exceptions abound. But, in general, that's been the trend. We are equally guilty of protectionism as other countries -- beef, sugar, corn, ethanol, etc etc are usually among the exemptions from lower tariffs we carve out in FTAs. Lobbyists, ya know.)
author: megancarpentier

text: According to unions, it was lax environmental standards, labor standards, etc, moreso than tariffs which, because of the WTO, PNTR and FTAs were trending down in most non-agricultural products and primary goods (i.e., raw materials) worldwide.
author: megancarpentier

text: In an increasingly tertiary economy — one focused less on manufacturing than on services — the biggest problems faced by American countries abroad (according to American businesses) was intellectual property, barriers to entry, different environmental standards for imports, etc.
author: megancarpentier

text: What the US began focusing on in WTO negotiations, PNTR for China/Russian (getting around a 1970s law that raised tariffs on Communist countries) and bilateral-multilateral "free" trade agreements (they're not really "free" trade) wasn't lowering tariffs. And for good reason!
author: megancarpentier

text: Note the essential stability of trade-weighted tariffs since the late 1970s; that's indicative of some hot air being blown about how much we've "lost" in trade negotiations. PNTR for China started in 2001.
author: megancarpentier

text: Here is a chart of US tariffs since the 1930s, when we raised tariffs to help our economy and caused a worldwide Great Depression, during which no one could buy anything. https://www.usitc.gov/publications/332/us_trade_policy_since1934_ir6_pub4094.pdf …
author: megancarpentier

text: Obviously, this has a distorting effect on pricing, making locally-produced goods have better comparative prices because of the taxes you're paying on imported ones. It is the epitome of government picking economic winners whether or not those businesses are viable.
author: megancarpentier

text: So, a little tariff talk: tariffs are essentially taxes, paid by consumers on imported goods. The more your government imposes tariffs on imports, the more you pay for those goods.
author: megancarpentier

text: It makes Christmases awkward, TBH.
author: megancarpentier

text: Twitter is the soul of brevity.
author: megancarpentier

text: BUT DO: Write me a 3-5 sentence pitch, in an email (it's in my Twitter bio!) explaining your thesis, the evidence for it and who you are/why you're the person to write it. Don't hear back? Follow up *politely* in 1 day for something time sensitive and 3 for something evergreen.
author: megancarpentier

text: UNDERSTAND YOU WILL BE EDITED: I get it, your words are special, my words are special, we're all special. But if you don't want strangers to edit you, get a personal blog/Tumblr, and stop pitching editors.
author: megancarpentier

text: DO NOT ASK ME TO REPUBLISH. Again, it's 2018. There is almost no benefit to me republishing, plus professional outlets *edit* you.
author: megancarpentier

text: DO NOT SIMULTANEOUSLY PITCH ME: If it is A) incredibly newsy and B) incredible time sensitive, put that in your pitch and give me a deadline. But every. single. editor has has a simul-pitch blow up in their face.
author: megancarpentier

text: DO NOT DM ME: I am a professional editor. I do not accept pitches via Twitter DM, Facebook message, Instagram, SnapChat, my personal email(s). My email is in my bio! I might ignore your email, but I'll still see it. (I will absolutely ignore your DM.)
author: megancarpentier

text: NEVER SEND ME ANYTHING ON A FRIDAY AFTERNOON. I get that you might do this in your free time, but you're going to get buried in my Inbox as I try to actually find a way to *have* free time. On my weekend. Not editing you.
author: megancarpentier

text: PEEP MY SITE. How many pieces do we publish a day? Did we just publish one on the thing you want to write about? Is literally nothing more than 1000 words and your piece is 2500? We might not be the right home for your piece, and better for you to know that than me tell you.
author: megancarpentier

text: DO NOT ASK ME TO MEET IN PERSON. I am not going to meet a stranger for coffee when I have work to do, and I would spike a shitty pitch from my own mother. Face time isn't going to help.
author: megancarpentier

text: TELL ME WHO YOU ARE AND WHY THAT IS RELEVANT. Again, you're asking for my attention (and my company's money), I'm not going to Google you to figure it out.
author: megancarpentier

text: DO NOT SEND UNSOLICITED ATTACHMENTS. People, it is 2018. Even if my OpSec was that poor, you're going to make me load Word and read some unknown number of words to decide on your idea? Nope.
author: megancarpentier

text: I think, if she released it (and, as the doctor said, he was allowed to be more specific than in previous administrations, so "if"'s the word there), yes, they would (it would've been read aloud on live TV, like Trump's was) and the fat-shaming would have people screaming.
author: megancarpentier

text: Meanwhile, a shout-out to every fucking ripped female trainer at my gym, all of whom weigh more than you’d expect a thin, fit woman to weigh. They’re hot as hell and will kick your ass if you tell them otherwise.
author: megancarpentier

text: The reason every single comparison of a professional athlete to Donald Trump annoys me (other than the fat-shaming) is that muscle weighs three times what fat does. Literally, you’re disproving your supposed point with every picture.
author: megancarpentier

text: I had to wear a back-closure corset under a bridesmaid's dress once. Enough said.
author: megancarpentier

text: Screw all the Uber-for-things-men-want suggestions. Hotels should offer a female concierge service for women to get in and out of formal wear. I have stood at many a hotel mirror with a tight-armed dress and high zipper and wondered about my sleeping options.
author: megancarpentier
